body: For some context the current master is broken because of javadoc generation referring to a method that does not exist in the current version of Kafka (0.10.x). Yesterday some changes to support Kafka 0.11.x were introduced. This is a quickfix for this.

It looks like the `@see` used instead of the `@link` that existed before doesn't seem to work in this context (inside a `@param`).
Since the problem is that the `@link` is broken when the client is not dependent on Kafka 0.11+ consider instead of the original code based `@link` to link instead to Kafka [GitHub](https://github.com/apache/kafka/blob/0.11.0.0/clients/src/main/java/org/apache/kafka/clients/producer/KafkaProducer.java#L549-L567)/[Javadoc](https://kafka.apache.org/0110/javadoc/org/apache/kafka/clients/producer/KafkaProducer.html#sendOffsetsToTransaction(java.util.Map,%20java.lang.String))
@staslev thanks for the comments ! Yeah, I tested with a local Spark 2 cluster. I'm preparing some docker images to do more loading tests.

KafkaIO support all the versions from 0.9 (that's missing pom update didn't cause build failure). May be better to move it to provided scope. Right now, if a user is building Beam manually they can set kafka.client.version (e.g. `mvn -pl sdks/java/io/kafka test -Dkafka.clients.version=0.9.0.1`).

Hm, not sure I understand how the profiles thing will work in practice.

For Beam contributors:
- When I make a change to Beam and run the usual "mvn clean verify", will that run unit tests against Spark1 dependencies, or against Spark2 dependencies, or both?
- If I say "Run Spark ValidatesRunner" on a PR: same question?
- Which will the default Java precommit run?

For Beam users:
- If I'm an external user and I specify a dependency on beam-runners-spark, will I get an artifact that supports launching jobs against only Spark1 or only against Spark2 or both? (an external user, of course, can not specify a build profile for Beam, because they are not building Beam, they are just fetching an already built artifact from the repo)
LGTM. I'll wait a bit for Jenkins.

I think a better solution than profiles is something @echauchot did to support different versions of Elasticsearch.

* Have a module beam-runners-spark-common containing almost all the current code of beam-runners-spark with a pom.xml that treats Spark deps as provided; beam-runners-spark (for Spark 1.x) that depends on -common and on Spark 1.x, beam-runners-spark2 (for Spark 2.x) that depends on -common and Spark 2.x. This way users can explicitly depend on either one or the other.

* Craft the pom.xml's so that runners-spark1 will run unit tests of spark-common against spark1, and runners-spark2 will run unit tests of spark-common against spark2. This way "mvn clean verify" will run both.

* Change Jenkins setup to refactor "Spark ValidatesRunner" into "Spark 1 ValidatesRunner" and "Spark 2 ValidatesRunner"

The purpose was to have a unique module as the code is exactly the same. We can have different modules, all code in common and just a pom with the dependencies set (no code). But it's basically a profile. I can draft a multi module layer but let me start with documenting profiles first.
Looks like 'run java precommit' spell has no power here.

I think before documenting this solution we need to make sure that this is the right solution, otherwise the documentation effort will be wasted work. To me it seems that the issues raised in my comment above are show-stoppers and warrant changing this to a multi-module implementation; am I missing something?
So having a module common with code and two modules just with a pom for dependencies is what you are proposing ? What's the pros comparing to profiles ?
Anyway I do what you propose but I think we can achieve the same just providing -Pspark1 or -Pspark2.

Motivational quote from chat:

_Hi. I feel like there is a misunderstanding about how profiles work - perhaps it is a misunderstanding on my side. Am I correct in thinking that, if I am an external user of Beam and I am simply specifying Beam as a dependency to be fetched from maven-central, then I can not specify -Pspark1 or -Pspark2?
AFAIK profiles are for the person who is building the project, not for the person who is using it as a dependency; you can not specify a <dependency> on "beam-runners-spark with -Pspark1"_

_And if I build my own pom.xml with -Pspark1, it will have no effect at all, or it will fail, because my pom.xml won't have a profile named "spark1"_

This was not closed properly because the "closes #3998" trick only applies to master. For the release branch, I recommend doing a proper merge commit instead. You can always rebase the PR first, and then do a merge. This will put the PR in a nearly linear chain but still maintain the correct git lineage.
Thanks. Closing.

Or may be we can just keep a shortcut as simple as possible at the moment, if users will want to customize then they'd start with an expanded ParseFiles, I guess something like ParseConfiguration can easily be introduced later on without affecting anything. So, unless you think introducing ParseConfiguration should be done earlier rather than later, I'll consider that the only major pending item is to make sure ParseResult can be reported in the case of the parsing failures, with the configuration improvements to follow at some later stage
I'm closing this PR because it's coverage is included in PR #3999 that also merges `AvroIOTransformTest` into `AvroIOTest`

I am not sure I follow the latest comments.

The profiles only add the 'provided' dependencies so for the end user they should not really do any different of what they already do (with the exception of putting the correct version of the spark dependencies). So one runner can cover in principle both versions and in that case we can just adapt the examples/tests/ci to do so. And with this cover all the cases listed by Eugene.

Also I am not sure if the comparison with ElasticsearchIO makes sense considering that there is only one implementation of the IO (not a common and two shared submodules). What Etienne did was to create two independent modules **only for the tests** of each version, is this what you propose @jkff ?

The 'big' advantage of having separated versions I see is if we want to include in the future a different TransformTranslator based on a different API (e.g. Structured Streaming) but at the time this will make sense Spark 1 will be already deprecated (Notice that Cloudera already started doing this).

Ping @amitsela to see if he has any preference on this ?

The idea is to simplify the experience for end users. I don't think that profiles approach is convenient for the user.
So basically, currently, I'm evaluating two approaches:
1. the user defines `beam-spark-runner` (unique) in his dependencies set in the `pom.xml`. Then, he will have to specify the Spark version related dependencies (or use a BoM).
2. the user has a choice of `beam-spark1-runner` and `beam-spark2-runner` acting as a BoM, providing a default coherent dependencies set.
I'm in favor of having:
* `common` with the code (both base and test)
* `spark1` with a pom, basically a BoM with dependencies
* `spark2` with a pom, basically a BoM with dependencies
Thanks to that, we can step by step improve `spark2` to smoothly add dataframe support.
By the way, I already started to refactore to use three modules.

R: @tgroh 
CC: @kennknowles 

I had a brief discussion with Ken about doing this high level approach since he had been the largest contributor to the PCollectionView interfaces from my memory. Ken, you might want to take a look at the high level interface changes.

I actually forgot the most important part, which was the part where we tell the runner harness where to find the pipeline. So this is mostly a total rewrite so I rebased anyhow; please take a fresh look.

 - The pipeline being "staged" is actually the `DataflowRunner` talking to the runner harness, so it isn't really part of the other staging logic that is the SDK/user pipeline talking to the SDK harness. The staging location just happens to be a convenient place where we know the client can write and the runner harness can read. So I went back to using the raw `stage_file` method but I am happy to use more appropriate helper logic if it exists.
 - The setting of the metadata `"pipeline_url"` to this proto is the common piece across SDKs. Everyone needs to put it somewhere accessible to the runner harness, but the SDK can choose where and set this field to anything. Is it a mandatory part of every job from now on.
 - It looks like the `stage_file` method returns nothing if staged to a local file or the full GCS `Object` (this is the `response`) if it is GCS. Normally, I would set the metadata field to maybe a URL returned by `stage_file` but I didn't want to mess with that. So the URL is hardcoded.

Incidentally, my formatting may or may not matter to you. I did some default IntelliJ autoformatting, because even though there is a `yapf` formatter I think it does whole files only. If you have a recommended tool or manual process I am happy to oblige.
